raw_comment:
1. I noticed that those who come from higher income families are more likely to get accepted into elite colleges unlike those who come from poor families. From the graph, I can see that families with a legacy are also more likely to to get accepted.
2. I wonder does this contribute to a greater cycle of higher income students who are able to get into elite colleges while those who come from poor families have a low chance of getting accepted. Is there any way to stop the cycle?
3. This relates to me and my community because I feel like everyone should have an equal opportunity to get into elite colleges. There are people who would love to attend college but can’t due to the high costs or lack of resources. 
4. A name for the graph could be “College Admissions: An Unfair Advantage”
ace_sentences: I noticed that students from higher-income families are more likely to be accepted into elite colleges than students from poor families.
From the graph, I see that students from legacy families are more likely to be accepted into elite colleges than students from non-legacy families.
I wonder whether this situation contributes to a cycle.
In this cycle, higher-income students are able to get into elite colleges.
In this cycle, students from poor families have a low chance of being accepted into elite colleges.
I ask whether there is a way to stop this cycle.
This situation relates to me and my community.
I think that everyone should have an equal opportunity to get into elite colleges.
Some people want to attend college.
Some people cannot attend college because of high costs.
Some people cannot attend college because of a lack of resources.
A name for the graph is "College Admissions: An Unfair Advantage".
